ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If you're considering taking it, do so. It's definitely manageable and Zhou Laoshi is a really good guy.
Yes, take it. Especially with Zhou laoshi. You will continue learning a lot. It's a demanding, yet rewarding class.

Pretty similar to 154, but for some reason this semester, the professor decided to assign substantially more homework than in the fall. I felt like this was more reminiscent of the 1.5 credit class workload, and I'm not sure whether that was a great choice for 2nd semester senior year. That said, Zhou Laoshi is an excellent teacher, and as always, I learned a lot in his class.

Chinese 155 is a great class. It's a clear continuation of 154, and Zhou Laoshi is wonderful. The topics (Food Culture, Architecture, Confucianism, Democracy, Chinese-Taiwanese relations) were interesting and Zhou Laoshi often included newspaper articles to diversify from the textbook, however it is still a language track class. It is a methodic, manageable and relatively low key way to continue improving in Chinese. We also got some good speaking practice with the periodic speeches/presentations we did of our essays.
It's good to learn grammar basics but a lot of what you learn slips through the cracks. It's a lot of work and a big time commitment.
